description: Croydon Council's bold 1990s Croydon Clocktower project created a large new central library. Former Town Hall library and other spaces were then re-purposed as arts venues which opened in 1995. These tours for 15 people will outline how this was achieved, with particular emphasis on the David Lean Cinema, and will include a brief talk on the cinema's eventful history.

factsheet.heading: Croydon Clocktower: repurposing spaces for arts use
paragraphs: In the early 1990s, Croydon Council's undertook a bold Â£30 million project which refurbished parts of the  Grade II listed Town Hall and sympathetically added a large new central library, at the back of the building.  This meant that former Town Hall areas that included library facilities and court rooms could be re-purposed, as arts venues which opened in 1995. The project created a striking new library, but this tour will focus on the project's final phase; an arts complex that offered a striking blend of Victorian and modern architecture. It was described by Time Out as "The jewel in Croydon's crown", but most cultural activity (including the David Lean Cinema) was suspended in 2011 due to major cuts to the Council's arts budget.

factsheet.heading: The history of the David Lean Cinema
paragraphs: The tour will provide an overview of how the Clocktower's arts venues were created, with particular emphasis on the cinema's auditorium, projection room and arts bar.  Trailers will be screened while small groups view the projection room. The concluding talk on the cinema's history will include it's distinctive attributes; the connection with David Lean; and notable people from the world of film production and exhibition who have worked for - or appeared at - the cinema. It will also touch upon the challenges of reopening the cinema in 2014, and running it as a Community Interest Company with approximately 90 volunteers.
